text: my name is dr. Oliver Johnson I'm a
British doctor leading a Kings Health
Partners team out in one hospital in
Freetown Sierra Leone every day we're
seeing more cases and our challenge now
is that our units full and so it's you
know it's becoming to the point where I
have to turn cases away or find out the
units for them and so it's this urgent
urgent need to increase bed capacity
about a month's ago the WHI said there
might be 20,000 dead and at the time I
thought impossible and suddenly people
are talking about worst-case scenario
more than a million deaths in West
Africa which is just for those of us who
thought at the beginning maybe this will
be one on 200 cases it's mind-blowing we
could end up seeing more cases a day
than we have seen in total in the last
six months
lots of my experiences here have been
doing things that as a doctor go
completely against what I would expect
do you see a patient collapse then in
Britain I'll rush over and do you know
basic life support here you know until
I'm fully suited up I've got to assume
that patient might have a bowler I can't
even go near them our moments where when
we've been completely full we've had her
with the government clothes the accident
and emergency button for a few hours
to see you know mothers with young kids
coming and you know desperately sick
crying begging but to know that if we if
we don't take the step now if we don't
close the department then I the whole
hospital could become overwhelmed so
it's a series of impossible choices
we're having to make that just scream
against what our instincts are as health
workers what's remarkable is that a lot
of patients come in and they can you
come in in the morning and they are
talking they're a little bit weak a
little bit tired but they're talking
okay and then by the evening they're
pretty confused and pretty frustrated
and then by the following morning you
come in and are dead and it's pretty
difficult I think for all of us all the
health workers here day in day out to be
sewing so many patients who are dying we
don't normally have many survivors but
we've had a few and there are a few
particular patients that often still
come back now that they're survivors to
say hello to us and that's been really
important for us as health workers to
know that there is light at the end of
the tunnel and that if we can get in
early with treatment and we can provide
the right kind of support then they can
they can make it and in the face of
what's really the horror of you know a
lot of death and poor outcomes
